cells.data:
Repeated roots:

Find $\lambda, u$ that form $e^{\lambda t} u$

Then, we seek $v$ such that we can construct $e^{\lambda t} u + t e^{\lambda t} v$, necessitating $(A - \lambda I)v = u$

We find that for an initial condition $Y_0$, the constants $c_1,c_2 = SY_0 = \matrixstart u & v \matrixend Y_0$

Further, the solution is then $Y(t) = e^{\lambda t} S \matrixstart 1 & t \\ 0 & 1 \matrixend S^{-1} Y_0$

Sketch: cf. wksht #$21$

In the $v$ direction, we have only $c_2e^{\lambda t}$
In the $u$ direction, we have the more complicated $e^{\lambda t}(c_1 + c_2t)$

Start with a brief look at physics/springs/systems of equations
(cf. wksht #$22$)
